---
title: 'Barriers and challenges to sustainable physical planning for mountain destinations
  and second-home developments in the mountain region of south-eastern Norway: the
  reign of governments or developers?'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publikasjon</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-6TXN5Q2D" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Tjørve, E., Tjørve, K. M. C., &#38; Owusu, K. (2022). Barriers and challenges to sustainable physical planning for mountain destinations and second-home developments in the mountain region of south-eastern Norway: the reign of governments or developers? <i>European Spatial Research and Policy</i>, <i>29</i>(2), 115–129. <a href="https://doi.org/10.18778/1231-1952.29.2.07">https://doi.org/10.18778/1231-1952.29.2.07</a></div> </div>

<div id="csl-bib-meta-6TXN5Q2D" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-6TXN5Q2D" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>Om</h1>
    Tjørve et al. undersøkte endringane i fysisk planlegging for fjelldestinasjonar i sør-austlege Noreg dei siste tretti åra. Dei fann at medan talet på hotell har gått ned, har det vore ein auke i privat eigde fritidsbustader. Denne endringa har ført til berekraftsproblem, ettersom planlegginga har gått frå lokalstyre til private utbyggjarar. Forfattarane peikar på at denne endringa har resultert i fragmentert utvikling, der langsiktige konsekvensar ofte blir oversett. Dei diskuterer korleis nyliberale trendar i planlegging og utfordringane små lokalsamfunn står overfor, bidreg til dårleg og ukontrollert utvikling. Denne studien er viktig fordi den viser korleis mangel på koordinert planlegging kan ha negativ innverknad på miljøet og lokalsamfunn i fjellområda.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-6TXN5Q2D" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Emneord</h1>
    Berekraftig fysisk planlegging, fjelldestinasjonar, fritidsbustader, lokalstyre, private utbyggjarar, nyliberal trend
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-6TXN5Q2D" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Samandrag</h1>
    The number of hotels in the mountains of south-eastern Norway has decreased over the last three decades, with a concurrent increase in the number of modern, privately-owned second homes. The growth of second-home villages and associated commercial activity has produced sustainability issues. The shift in the planning and development process from the local government to private developers has resulted in a piece-by-piece process with the loss of sight of long-term consequences. This short review discusses the causes of uncontrolled or poor planning of mountain regions; in particular, the neoliberal trend in physical planning and the problem of small local communities.
  </article>
